COMMON.MSG_DETAILS_TABDETAILS_RESOURCEQUOTADETA:
Requests are the amount of resources you expect to use. These are used when establishing if the cluster can fulfill your Request.

Limits are a maximum amount of a resource you can consume. Applications consuming more than the Limit may be terminated.

A cluster administrator can establish limits on both the amount you can Request and your Limits with a Resource Quota.

GENERAL.MSG_SERVICEBROKERS_MAIN_DESCRIPTION_1: A representation of a service broker for a specific namespace, encapsulating its server connection details. These are created and managed by operators who wish to use that broker server to make new types of managed services available within their namespace.
GENERAL.MSG_SERVICEBROKERS_CREATEYAML_DIV1_1: Add a service broker made available by a service provider to be used in a namespace.
GENERAL.MSG_SERVICECLASSES_MAIN_DESCRIPTION_1: A managed service offered by a particular service broker. When a new ServiceBroker resource is added to the namespace, the Service Catalog controller connects to the service broker to obtain a list of available managed services. It then creates a new ServiceClass resource corresponding to each managed service.
GENERAL.MSG_SERVICEPLANS_MAIN_DESCRIPTION_1: A specific offering of a managed service. For example, a managed service may have different plans available, such as a free tier or paid tier, or it may have different configuration options, such as using SSD storage or having more resources. Similar to ServiceClass, when a new ServiceBroker is added to the cluster, Service Catalog creates a new ServicePlan resource corresponding to each Service Plan available for each managed service.
GENERAL.MSG_CLUSTERSERVICEBROKERS_MAIN_DESCRIPTI: An in-cluster representation of a service broker, encapsulating its server connection details. These are created and managed by cluster operators who wish to use that broker server to make new types of managed services available within their cluster.
GENERAL.MSG_CLUSTERSERVICEBROKERS_CREATEYAML_DIV: Add a service broker made available by a service provider to be used in across the cluster.

Register a service cluster broker for users to use service catalog templates.
User a cluster service broker to use the service broker in entire cluster.
GENERAL.MSG_CLUSTERSERVICECLASSES_MAIN_DESCRIPTI: A managed service offered by a particular service broker. When a new ClusterServiceBroker resource is added to the cluster, the Service Catalog controller connects to the service broker to obtain a list of available managed services. It then creates a new ClusterServiceClass resource corresponding to each managed service.
GENERAL.MSG_CLUSTERSERVICEPLANS_MAIN_DESCRIPTION: A specific offering of a managed service. For example, a managed service may have different plans available, such as a free tier or paid tier, or it may have different configuration options, such as using SSD storage or having more resources. Similar to ClusterServiceClass, when a new ClusterServiceBroker is added to the cluster, Service Catalog creates a new ClusterServicePlan resource corresponding to each Service Plan available for each managed service.
GENERAL.MSG_SERVICEINSTANCES_MAIN_DESCRIPTION_1: A provisioned instance of a ServiceClass or a ClusterServiceClass. These are created by cluster operators to make a specific instance of a managed service available for use by one or more in-cluster applications. When a new ServiceInstance resource is created, the Service Catalog controller connects to the appropriate service broker and instruct it to provision the service instance.
GENERAL.MSG_SERVICEINSTANCES_CREATEFORM_STEP1_DI: Select a service class from the namespace to which you have access.
GENERAL.MSG_SERVICEINSTANCES_CREATEYAML_DIV3_TAB: Create a provisioning instance of cluster service class.
GENERAL.MSG_SERVICEBINDINGS_MAIN_DESCRIPTION_1: Access credentials to a ServiceInstance. These are created by cluster operators who want their applications to make use of a ServiceInstance. Upon creation, the Service Catalog controller creates a Kubernetes Secret containing connection details and credentials for the Service Instance, which can be mounted into Pods.
GENERAL.MSG_SERVICEBINDINGS_CREATEYAML_DIV3_TABS: Service binding serves to provide the connection between the service instance and application program.
2. Service Binding Secret Key Addition Sample

Service binding serves to provide the connection between the service instance and application program. When the broker responds, the service catalog records the credentials that it responds with into the secret specified in spec.secretName.
GENERAL.MSG_CATALOGSERVICECLAIMS_MAIN_DESCRIPTIO: A Catalog Service Claim allows the user to request a new catalog service template from the cluster administrator.
GENERAL.MSG_CATALOGSERVICECLAIMS_CREATEYAML_DIV1: Request a new catalog service by specifying a service template.
GENERAL.MSG_TEMPLATES_MAIN_DESCRIPTION_1: Templates allow users to specify all objects and parameters for an application so that the app may be easily deployed later once the template is created.
GENERAL.MSG_TEMPLATES_CREATEYAML_DIV1_1: Specify the objects and parameters for an application to create a template.
GENERAL.MSG_TEMPLATES_CREATEYAML_DIV3_TABSAMPLE_: Defining a template enables you to easily recreate all objects in your application. The template defines the created objects and metadata.
GENERAL.MSG_TEMPLATEINSTANCES_MAIN_DESCRIPTION_1: Template Instances allow users to deploy a new application instance based on the specifications included in the selected service template.
GENERAL.MSG_TEMPLATEINSTANCES_CREATEFORM_DIV1_1: Enter the parameters required by the template to deploy the application.

Use the registered template (gitlab-template) to create template instances, and select one from the service instances.
2. Create a template instance using apache-cicd-template
Use template (apache-cicd-template) to deploy applications with GitLab CI/CD, and select one from the service instances.

GENERAL.MSG_DEPLOYMENTS_MAIN_DESCRIPTION_1:
A Deployment provides declarative updates for Pods and ReplicaSets.

Describe a desired state in a Deployment. The Deployment Controller changes the actual state to the desired state at a controlled rate. You can define Deployments to create new ReplicaSets, or to remove existing Deployments and adopt all their resources with new Deployments.
GENERAL.MSG_DEPLOYMENTS_CREATEFORM_DIV1_DESCRIPT: Create a Deployment by specifying the container image(s) as well as parameters shown below.
GENERAL.MSG_DEPLOYMENTS_CREATEFORM_DIV2_7: Press Enter to add the Label.
GENERAL.MSG_DEPLOYMENTS_CREATEFORM_DIV2_9: The default entry point of the docker image and default cmd are overwritten when defining that value.
GENERAL.MSG_DEPLOYMENTS_CREATEFORM_DIV2_11: The default entry point of the docker image is overwritten when defining that value.
GENERAL.MSG_DEPLOYMENTS_CREATEYAML_DIV3_TABSCHEM: Deployment enables declarative updates for Pods and ReplicaSets.
Specification of the desired behavior of the Deployment.
Most recently observed status of the Deployment.
GENERAL.MSG_DEPLOYMENTS_CREATEYAML_DIV3_TABSAMPL: Use the nginx image to create a deployment consisting of one Pod.
2. Create a deployment consisting of 3 Pods

Use the nginx image to create a deployment consisting of 3 Pods. 
A threshold can be set so that the created Pod is ready in 10 seconds (minReadySeconds option).
3. Create a deployment by configuring rollong update.

When you create a deployment with the rolling update strategy, it upgrades the image by continuing to add 30% new Pods and delete 30% old Pods. 
If no policy is specified, maxSure and maxUnavailable are set by 25% by default.
4. Create a deployment by mounting volumes

Create a hostPath persistent volume in deployment creation. 
Set a hostpath volume using the real path of the node directory.
GENERAL.MSG_STATEFULSETS_MAIN_DESCRIPTION_1:
StatefulSets are useful for applications that require one or more of the following:

Stable, unique network identifiers.
Stable, persistent storage.
Ordered, graceful deployment and scaling.
Ordered, automated rolling updates.

In the above, stable is the same property as Pod rescheduling. If an application doesn't need stable identifiers or ordered deployment, deletion, or scaling, you should deploy your application using a workload object that provides a set of stateless replicas. Deployment or ReplicaSet may suit better to the user's stateless needs.
GENERAL.MSG_STATEFULSETS_CREATEFORM_DIV1_DESCRIP: Manage the deployment and scaling of a set of Pods.
GENERAL.MSG_STATEFULSETS_CREATEFORM_DIV2_5: Press Enter to add the Label.
GENERAL.MSG_STATEFULSETS_CREATEFORM_DIV2_12: Create a volume claim in the StatefulSet.
GENERAL.MSG_STATEFULSETS_CREATEYAML_DIV3_TABSAMP: 1. Create 3 Pods for a StatefulSet by default

Create 3 StatefulSet Pods with unique identities. 
The desired number of Pods can be set by entering the replica value. (Default: 1)
2. Create Pods in parallel when running StatefulSets

Pod management policies can be used to create and launch Pods in parallel.
OrderedReady is the default policy where Pods are created in increasing order and the controller will wait until each Pod is ready before continuing.
3. Set the number of revisions to be maintained for a StatefulSet

The maximum number of revisions that will be maintained in the StatefulSet's revision history.
(Default: 10)
Terminate each Pod, and waits for it to transition to running and ready prior to updating the next Pod.
GENERAL.MSG_SECRETS_MAIN_DESCRIPTION_1: Secrets let you store and manage sensitive information, such as passwords, OAuth tokens, and ssh keys. Storing confidential information in a Secret is safer and more flexible than putting it verbatim in a Pod definition or in a container image.

GENERAL.MSG_CONFIGMAPS_MAIN_DESCRIPTION_1:
Most types of Kubernetes secrets store sensitive information and ConfigMaps store general configuration information, such as groups of configuration files. Because ConfigMap doesn't store sensitive information, they can be updated automatically, so unlike most Kubernetes secrets that require manual updates and container restarts, there is no need to restart the container.

ConfigMaps accept key value pairs in common string formats, like config files or JSON blobs. After you upload a config map, any workload can reference it as an environment variable or a volume mount.
GENERAL.MSG_CONFIGMAPS_CREATEFORM_DIV1_DESCRIPTI: Decouple configuration artifacts by specifying the required configuration values for the container.

GENERAL.MSG_CRONJOBS_MAIN_DESCRIPTION_1:
A CronJob creates Jobs on a time-based schedule. One CronJob object is like one line of a crontab (cron table) file. It runs a job periodically on a given schedule, written in Cron format.

When creating the manifest for a CronJob resource, make sure the name you provide is a valid DNS subdomain name. The name must be no longer than 52 characters. This is because the CronJob controller will automatically append 11 characters to the job name provided and there is a constraint that the maximum length of a Job name is no more than 63 characters.
GENERAL.MSG_CRONJOBS_CREATEFORM_STEP1_DIV1_1: Run CronJobs periodically at fixed times, dates, or intervals.
GENERAL.MSG_CRONJOBS_CREATEFORM_STEP1_DIV2_7:
Schedule Input Method
- Asterisk (*) for all
- Comma (,) is used to separate list items.
- Dash (-) is used to separate the range.

GENERAL.MSG_JOBS_MAIN_DESCRIPTION_1:
Create one or more Pods and end the specified number of Pods successfully.

An example is to create one Job object to reliably run a Pod. The Job object will start a new Pod if the first Pod fails or is deleted (for example, due to a node hardware failure or a node reboot).

You can also run multiple Pods in parallel using jobs.
GENERAL.MSG_JOBS_CREATEFORM_DIV2_5: If you specify a label selector which is not unique to the Pods of that job, and which matches unrelated Pods, the Pods of the unrelated job may be deleted, or this job may count other Pods as being completed, or one or both jobs may refuse to create Pods or run to completion. If a non-unique selector is selected, other controllers (e.g. ReplicationController) and their Pods may operate in unpredictable ways.
GENERAL.MSG_JOBS_CREATEFORM_DIV2_8: Press Enter to add the Label.
GENERAL.MSG_JOBS_CREATEFORM_DIV2_12: Define the number of retries when the job fails.
GENERAL.MSG_JOBS_CREATEFORM_DIV2_14: Define the deadline for job execution time. (If the deadline is exceeded, the job is forcibly terminated and changed to a failed state.)
GENERAL.MSG_JOBS_CREATEFORM_DIV2_16: Define when to delete jobs that have completed successfully. (If not set, the job will not be deleted.)

GENERAL.MSG_DAEMONSETS_MAIN_DESCRIPTION_1:
Use a DaemonSet when a copy of a Pod always runs on all or specific hosts, and when it needs to start before other Pods.

DaemonSets are similar to Deployments in that they create Pods, and those Pods have non-terminated processes (e.g. web servers, storage servers). Use a Deployment for stateless services, like frontends, where scaling up the number of replicas and updating are more important than controlling the host which the Pod runs on.
GENERAL.MSG_DAEMONSETS_CREATEFORM_DIV1_DESCRIPTI: Create specific Pods to run on all or some nodes in the cluster.
GENERAL.MSG_DAEMONSETS_CREATEFORM_DIV2_5: Press Enter to add the Label.
GENERAL.MSG_DAEMONSETS_CREATEFORM_DIV2_18: Press Enter to add the Label.
GENERAL.MSG_DAEMONSETS_CREATEFORM_DIV2_56: Select the new Pod creation method when updating from the DaemonSet template.
GENERAL.MSG_REPLICASETS_MAIN_DESCRIPTION_1:
A ReplicaSet ensures that a specified number of Pod replicas are running at any given time.

However, a Deployment is a higher-level concept that manages ReplicaSets and provides declarative updates to Pods along with a lot of other useful features. Therefore, we recommend using Deployments instead of directly using ReplicaSets, unless you require custom update orchestration or don't require updates at all.
GENERAL.MSG_REPLICASETS_CREATEYAML_DIV3_TABSCHEM: ReplicaSet ensures that a specified number of pod replicas are running at any given time.
GENERAL.MSG_REPLICASETS_CREATEYAML_DIV3_TABSAMPL: 1. Run a single ReplicaSet by default

Run the default number of Pod replica (1).
One Pod is executed by default if not specified.
3. Run ReplicaSet Pods after the delay period of seconds.
Run 3 Pod replicas. When creating a replica Pod, it is set to wait 10 seconds (minReadySeconds option) to avoid container crashing. (Default: 0)
4. Run 2 ReplicaSets that match the requirements of the Pod selector
Run the Pods that match the list of Pod selector requirements through matchExpressions as well as matchLabels.
GENERAL.MSG_HORIZONTALPODAUTOSCALERS_MAIN_DESCRI:
The Horizontal Pod Autoscaler(HPA) automatically scales the number of Pods in a deployment, replica set or stateful set based on observed CPU, memory, and/or custom metric utilization.

The HPA will periodically adjust the number of replicas in a deployment to match the observed average CPU utilization to the target specified by user.
GENERAL.MSG_HORIZONTALPODAUTOSCALERS_CREATEFORM_: Automatically scale the number of Pods in a a replication controller, deployment, ReplicaSet or StatefulSet based on observed CPU utilization.
Supports automatic scaling of deployment and replication sets based on specified metrics.
GENERAL.MSG_HORIZONTALPODAUTOSCALERS_CREATEYAML_: HorizontalPodAutoscaler is the configuration for a horizontal pod autoscaler, which automatically manages the replica count of any resource implementing the scale subresource based on the metrics specified.
1. Create a HPA based on CPU

AutoScaling occurs when the Pod's CPU utilization exceeds 50%.
The minimum number of Pods is 1, and the maximum number of Pods is 3. AutoScale condition (targetAverageUtilization/ targetAverageValue)
1. Create a HPA based on memory

AutoScaling occurs when the Pod's memory usage exceeds 100 Mi.
The minimum number of Pods is 1, and the maximum number of Pods is 5. AutoScale condition (targetAverageUtilization/ targetAverageValue)

GENERAL.MSG_VIRTUALMACHINES_CREATEYAML_DIV3_TABS:
Create VM objects for CentOS 6 virtual machines.
.spec.template.spec-device and resource settings

HyperCloud allows users to create, add, and manage virtual machines directly from the web console. 
By adopting KubeVirt technology, HyperCloud provides a unified development platform where developers can build, modify, and deploy applications residing in both Application Containers as well as Virtual Machines in a common, shared environment.
Create a virtual machine by following the instructions below.
GENERAL.MSG_SERVICES_MAIN_DESCRIPTION_1:
A Service is an abstract way to expose an application running on a set of Pods as a network service without having to modify the application to use an unfamiliar service discovery mechanism. Kubernetes gives Pods their own IP addresses and a single DNS name for a set of Pods, and can load-balance across them.
There three types of Services:
- ClusterIP: Exposes the Service on a cluster-internal IP. Choosing this value makes the Service only reachable from within the cluster. This is the default ServiceType.
- NodePort: Exposes the Service on each Node's IP at a static port (the NodePort). A ClusterIP Service, to which the NodePort Service routes, is automatically created. You'll be able to contact the NodePort Service, from - outside the cluster, by requesting <NodeIP>:<NodePort>.
- LoadBalancer: Exposes the Service externally using a cloud provider's load balancer. NodePort and ClusterIP Services, to which the external load balancer routes, are automatically created.
GENERAL.MSG_SERVICES_CREATEFORM_DIV1_DESCRIPTION: Specify the port and service type to create a service.
GENERAL.MSG_SERVICES_CREATEYAML_DIV3_TABSAMPLE_1: 1. Create a service of type ClusterIP (Default).
GENERAL.MSG_SERVICES_CREATEYAML_DIV3_TABSAMPLE_2:
Specify the Pod by a selector. A Pod is created by specifying the service port and target port to be exposed.

A cluster IP (Internal IP) is allocated.
GENERAL.MSG_SERVICES_CREATEYAML_DIV3_TABSAMPLE_3: 2. Create a service of type LoadBalancer.
GENERAL.MSG_SERVICES_CREATEYAML_DIV3_TABSAMPLE_4:
Specify the Pod by a selector. A Pod is created by specifying the service port (80, 443) and target port (9000, 9443) to be exposed.

A load balancer with an external IP is allocated.
GENERAL.MSG_SERVICES_CREATEYAML_DIV3_TABSAMPLE_5: 3. Create a service of type NodePort.
GENERAL.MSG_SERVICES_CREATEYAML_DIV3_TABSAMPLE_6:
Specify the Pod by a selector. A Pod is created by specifying the service port and target port to be exposed.

You can specify your own nodePort value in the 30000--32767 range. However, it is recommended that HyperCloud automatically allocates a nodePort for you.
GENERAL.MSG_SERVICES_CREATEYAML_DIV3_TABSAMPLE_7: 4. Create a service of type ExternalName.

Map to a service to a DNS names, not a typical selector service.
When looking up the host Example-service.default.svc.cluster.local, the cluster DNS Service returns a CNAME record with the value example-service.com.
GENERAL.MSG_INGRESSES_MAIN_DESCRIPTION_1: Ingress exposes HTTP and HTTPS routes from outside the cluster to services within the cluster. Traffic routing is controlled by rules defined on the Ingress resource. An Ingress may be configured to give Services externally-reachable URLs, load balance traffic, terminate SSL / TLS, and offer name-based virtual hosting.
GENERAL.MSG_INGRESSES_CREATEFORM_DIV1_DESCRIPTIO: Specify the host and parameters below to create an ingress resource.
GENERAL.MSG_INGRESSES_CREATEYAML_DIV3_TABSAMPLE_: 1. Create an ingress that maps to a service in the cluster.
For inbound HTTP requests, a backend service is required to process the requests mapped to a specific domain and prefix information.
You can add and execute backend services without basic rules.
GENERAL.MSG_NETWORKPOLICIES_MAIN_DESCRIPTION_1: The network policy allows Pod groups to communicate each other or with an endpoint of another network. Network policy resources select Pods by using labels and define rules specifying traffics allowed to the selected Pods. The policy is implemented with network plug-ins and can be used by using a networking solution that supports the policy.
GENERAL.MSG_NETWORKPOLICIES_CREATEFORM_DIV1_1: Allow Pod groups to communicate each other or with an endpoint of another network.
GENERAL.MSG_NETWORKPOLICIES_CREATEFORM_DIV2_6: You can add a label by pressing Enter.
GENERAL.MSG_NETWORKPOLICIES_CREATEFORM_DIV2_8: Define network rules for requests coming from the external of the namespace.
GENERAL.MSG_NETWORKPOLICIES_CREATEFORM_DIV2_10: Define network rules for requests sending to the external of the namespace.
GENERAL.MSG_NETWORKPOLICIES_CREATEYAML_DIV3_TABS: NetworkPolicy describes what network traffic is allowed for a set of Pods
GENERAL.MSG_PERSISTENTVOLUMES_MAIN_DESCRIPTION_1:
A Persistent Volume (PV) is a piece of storage in the cluster that has been provisioned by an administrator or dynamically provisioned using Storage Classes. 
A PV captures the details of the implementation of the storage, be that NFS, iSCSI, or a cloud-provider-specific storage system.
GENERAL.MSG_PERSISTENTVOLUMES_CREATEFORM_DIV1_DE: Create a Persistent Volume (PV) by specifying the Storage Class in addition to other parameters. The PV will be available for use by other cluster users.
GENERAL.MSG_PERSISTENTVOLUMES_CREATEFORM_DIV2_17: To use a raw block device, set it as block.
GENERAL.MSG_PERSISTENTVOLUMES_CREATEFORM_DIV2_22: Set the Pod permission to access the volume.
GENERAL.MSG_PERSISTENTVOLUMES_CREATEFORM_DIV2_28: Set a policy for persistent volumes by specifying the storage class.
GENERAL.MSG_PERSISTENTVOLUMES_CREATEFORM_DIV2_33: If you delete unnecessary persistent volume claims, select a policy to handle the remaining persistent volumes.
GENERAL.MSG_PERSISTENTVOLUMES_CREATEYAML_DIV3_TA: PersistentVolume (PV) is a storage resource provisioned by an administrator. It is analogous to a node. More info:
1. Create a PersistentVolume in ReadWriteOnce mode
Mount a volume as read-write in a single node, and delete the PersistentVolume after use.
2. Create a PersistentVolume in ReadOnlyMany mode
Mount a volume as read-only in multiple nodes, and not delete but store the PersistentVolume after use.
3. Create a PersistentVolume in ReadWriteMany Mode

Mount a volume as read-write in a single node, and delete the PersistentVolume after use. 
ReadWriteMany is applicable only when the block storage class is used and the volumeMode is Block.

To use plug-in type storage, detailed specifications (nfs, mountOptions) are required. After using a PersistentVolume, you can delete the data and reuse the data in a new PersistentVolumeClaim. 
Recycle is only available when plug-in type is nfs or hostpath.
GENERAL.MSG_PERSISTENTVOLUMESCLAIMS_MAIN_DESCRIP:
A PersistentVolumeClaim (PVC) is a request for storage by a user. A PVC can request specific size and access modes.
When none of the PVs match a user's PersistentVolumeClaim, the cluster may try to dynamically provision a volume specially for the PVC. This provisioning is based on StorageClasses: the PVC must request a storage class and the administrator must have created and configured that class for dynamic provisioning to occur.
GENERAL.MSG_PERSISTENTVOLUMESCLAIMS_CREATEFORM_D: Create a request for a PV by specifying storage configurations.
Set the Pod permission to access the volume.
To use a raw block device, set it as block.
Only persistent volume of the requested class can be bound.
Enter the size of storage to be requested.
Press Enter to add the Label.
Specify keys, lists of values, and operators related to keys and values.
GENERAL.MSG_PERSISTENTVOLUMESCLAIMS_CREATEYAML_D: PersistentVolumeClaim is a user's request for and claim to a persistent volume
1. Create 1 Gi file storage in the RWX mode

Create 1 Gi file storage using a storage class. Multiple Pods can be connected and read/written.
ReadWriteOnce: The volume can be mounted as read-write by a single Pod. ReadOnlyMany: The volume can be mounted as read by multiple Pods. ReadWriteMany: The volume can be mounted as read-write by multiple Pods.
2. Create 1 Gi block storage in the ROX mode

Use a storage class to create 1 Gi block storage. Multiple Pods can be mounted as read-only.
(volumeMode: Filesystem (Default)/Block)
3. Create a PersistentVolumeClamin in the RWX mode with your PersistentVolume

Use the PersistentVolume (volumeName) you created to create a PersistentVolumeClaim in RWX mode. 
The PersistentVolumeClaim’s access modes and resource requests must be satisfied in order for the PersistentVolume and PersistentVolumeClaim to be bound.
4. Create a PersistentVolumeClaim of the RWX mode to meet the conditions of the selector.
Use a storage class to create a PersistentVolumeClaim of the RWX mode which will be bound with the PersistentVolume based on the matching labels.
GENERAL.MSG_STORAGECLASSES_MAIN_DESCRIPTION_1: A Storage Class provides a way for administrators to describe the
GENERAL.MSG_STORAGECLASSES_CREATEFORM_DIV1_DESCR: Create a Storage Class by specifying the provisioner, parameters, and reclaimPolicy.
GENERAL.MSG_STORAGECLASSES_CREATEFORM_DIV2_3: Specify the volume plugin used for provisioning of persistent volumes. Different parameters may be set depending on the selected provisioner.
GENERAL.MSG_STORAGECLASSES_CREATEFORM_DIV2_13: Set management policy for the created persistent volumes.
GENERAL.MSG_STORAGECLASSES_CREATEYAML_DIV3_TABSC: StorageClass describes the parameters for a class of storage for which PersistentVolumes can be dynamically provisioned.
GENERAL.MSG_STORAGECLASSES_CREATEYAML_DIV3_TABSA: 1. Create a storage through dynamic volume binding
Specify the WaitForFirstConsumer mode to enable Pods dynamically create storage classes upon creation and bind them to the volume.
2. Create a block storage class using rook-ceph
Use rook-ceph to create a block storage class.
3. Create a storage class using Ceph-fs
Use Ceph-fs to create a block storage class.
GENERAL.MSG_DATAVOLUMES_MAIN_DESCRIPTION_1: Data volumes are used to automate the creation and population of a PVC with VM data. Data volumes are more suited for VM workloads over standard PVCs since it provide full functionality, a stable API, and better integration with VM features and capabilities.
GENERAL.MSG_DATAVOLUMES_CREATEFORM_DIV1_DESCRIPT: Create a Data Volume by specifying a VM image source and PVC configuration details.
GENERAL.MSG_DATAVOLUMES_CREATEYAML_DIV3_TABSAMPL: 1. Create a DataVolume using HTTP URL

Import a VM image using HTTP URL to create a DataVolume.
Content type (kubevirt (default), archive)/ volumeMode (Filesystem (default), block)

Import a VM image using s3 to create a DataVolume.
ReadWriteMany is allowed because volumeMode is set to block.
3. Create a DataVolume using a registry
Import a VM image using a registry to create a DataVolume.
GENERAL.MSG_TASKS_MAIN_DESCRIPTION_1: A Task is a collection of Steps that you define and arrange in a specific order of execution as part of your continuous integration flow. A Task executes as a Pod on your Kubernetes cluster.
GENERAL.MSG_TASKS_CREATFORM_DIV1_DESCRIPTION_1: Define a series of steps which launch specific build or delivery tools that ingest specific inputs and produce specific outputs.
GENERAL.MSG_TASKS_CREATFORM_DIV2_16: If provided as an option, you can allocate Pipeline resources as needed from the TaskRun or Pipeline menu.
GENERAL.MSG_TASKS_CREATFORM_DIV2_25: If no parameter is entered when creating a TaskRun or Pipeline, it is set to the default value.
GENERAL.MSG_TASKS_CREATFORM_DIV2_46: Please add the volume to be mounted first.

GENERAL.MSG_TASKS_CREATEYAML_DIV3_TABSAMPLE_4: Create a task by getting flags and sample URL items as parameters.
GENERAL.MSG_TASKRUNS_MAIN_DESCRIPTION_1: A TaskRun allows you to instantiate and execute a Task on-cluster. A Task specifies one or more Steps that execute container images and each container image performs a specific piece of build work. A TaskRun executes the Steps in the Task in the order they are specified until all Steps have executed successfully or a failure occurs.
GENERAL.MSG_TASKRUNS_CREATEFORM_DIV1_1: Instantiate a Task for execution with specific inputs, outputs, and execution parameters. Can be invoked on its own or as part of a Pipeline.
GENERAL.MSG_TASKRUNS_CREATEFORM_DIV2_13: You can specify a value for the timeout in minutes. If a value is not specified, the default global timeout settings are applied. If the value is set to 0, TaskRun is not started.
GENERAL.MSG_TASKRUNS_CREATEFORM_DIV2_16: You can execute the Task in your TaskRun with a specific set of credentials by specifying a ServiceAccount. If you do not explicitly specify this, the TaskRun executes with the credentials specified in the configmap-defaults ConfigMap. If this default is not specified, TaskRuns will execute with the default service account set for the target namespace.
GENERAL.MSG_TASKRUNS_CREATEYAML_DIV3_TABSAMPLE_1: 1. Create a TaskRun that runs a task
GENERAL.MSG_TASKRUNS_CREATEYAML_DIV3_TABSAMPLE_2: Use the resources created by a pipeline resource to create a Pod and run a task.

GENERAL.MSG_IMAGEREGISTRIES_MAIN_DESCRIPTION_1: HyperCloud supports the creation of private registries for container images. Hosting a registry inside your cluster is the fastest possible way to push and pull images, which matters for use cases such as auto-scaling and deploy images from a CI/CD pipeline.
GENERAL.MSG_IMAGEREGISTRIES_CREATEFORM_DIV1_1: Specify the parameters below to create a private registry.
GENERAL.MSG_IMAGEREGISTRIES_CREATEFORM_DIV2_6: Enter an image address of a registry to create.
GENERAL.MSG_IMAGEREGISTRIES_CREATEFORM_DIV2_20: Create a network policy by selecting a service type of a registry to create.
GENERAL.MSG_IMAGEREGISTRIES_CREATEFORM_DIV2_25: For use in the registry to be created, create a new persistent volume claim or select an already created persistent volume claim.
GENERAL.MSG_IMAGEREGISTRIES_CREATEFORM_DIV2_32: For use in the registry to be created, create a new persistent volume claim or select an already created persistent volume claim.
GENERAL.MSG_IMAGEREGISTRIES_CREATEFORM_DIV2_35: Press Enter to add a label.
GENERAL.MSG_IMAGEREGISTRIES_CREATEYAML_DIV3_TABS: 1. Create DemonSets on all nodes of the cluster

1) Create a DaemonSet using the image of DockerHub (apache).
2) A resource-limited Pod is created with 0.2 GB of CPU/0.1 Core/Memory on all nodes of the cluster.
2. Create DemonSets except for the Master node

Create DaemonSet Pods using DockerHub (apache) image. Pods with limited resources are created with CPU 0.1 Core/Memory 0.2 GB on all nodes except the master node. (Even if it is a master node, a Pod is created if node-role.kubernetes.io/master does not exist in Taint.)
3. Create a DemonSet with an update strategy

1) Create a DaemonSet using DockerHub (apache) image, and Pods are created on all nodes that make up the cluster.
2) Can select an update strategy (RollingUpdate, OnDelete (default)) for the Pod image.
3) minReadySeconds sets the waiting time of the created Pod. (Ddefault: 0)
GENERAL.MSG_SERVICEACCOUNTS_CREATEFORM_DIV1_1: Represents an identity for processes that run in a Pod.
GENERAL.MSG_SERVICEACCOUNTS_CREATEYAML_DIV3_TABS: ServiceAccount binds together: * a name, understood by users, and perhaps by peripheral systems, for an identity * a principal that can be authenticated and authorized * a set of secrets

It can be created for enabling the HyperCloud API or granting the access the API. As soon as a service account is created, secrets are automatically added to it

GENERAL.MSG_ROLEBINDINGS_MAIN_DESCRIPTION_1:
A RoleBinding grants the permissions defined in a role to a user or set of users. It holds a list of subjects (users, groups, or service accounts), and a reference to the role being granted. A RoleBinding grants permissions within a specific namespace whereas a ClusterRoleBinding grants that access cluster-wide.

A RoleBinding may reference any Role in the same namespace. Alternatively, a RoleBinding can reference a ClusterRole and bind that ClusterRole to the namespace of the RoleBinding. If you want to bind a ClusterRole to all the namespaces in your cluster, you use a ClusterRoleBinding.

A Role Binding Claim allows the user to request new roles to be associated with users or user groups.
GENERAL.MSG_ROLEBINDINGS_CREATEROLEBINDINGFORM_D: Associate a user/group to the selected role to define the type of access and resources that are allowed.
Grant the permissions to a user or set of users within the selected namespace.
Grant the permissions to a user or set of users at the cluster level and in all namespaces.
GENERAL.MSG_ROLEBINDINGS_CREATEROLEBINDINGCLAIMF: Request a new role binding by specifying a role and subject.

Determine if any container in a Pod can use privileged mode.
Pods are created only when the privileged option is false, and the privileged option of the security context must be set to false.

Specify a user other than the root user when creating a Pod.
This is applicable only if RunAsUser is not set as root in the security context setting.
Specify a user group for the users with the policy when creating a Pod.
Specify a certain type of volume to the Pod. Only volumes defined through the volume option can be used.
Cannot use the Linux features declared through the requiredDropCapabilities option when creating a Pod.

GENERAL.MSG_LIMITRANGES_MAIN_DESCRIPTION_1:
An administrator can restrict to create and use resources for each namespace by using resource quota. In each namespace, a Pod or container can use as much CPU and memory as defined by the resource quota. In this case, a single Pod or container can monopolize all available resources. LimitRange is a policy that limits resources that are allocated to Pods and containers in namespaces.

A LimitRange provides the following constraints.
- Specify minimum and maximum compute resources usage for each Pod or Container in a namespace.
- Specify minimum and maximum storage requests for each storage class in a namespace.
- Specify a ratio between request and limit for a resource in a namespace.
- Set default request/limit for compute resources in a namespace and automatically inject them to Containers at runtime.
GENERAL.MSG_LIMITRANGES_CREATELIMITRANGEFORM_DIV: Limit resource usage per Pod, Container, and PersistentVolumeClaim type in a namespace.
You can add a label by pressing Enter.
Set the limit range for each resource type of Pods to be created within the namespace.
GENERAL.MSG_LIMITRANGES_CREATELIMITRANGEYAML_DIV: LimitRange sets resource usage limits for each kind of resource in a Namespace.
Namespaces are a logical partitioning capability that allows you to specify resource allocation range such as CPU and memory. The claim function is used to enable the resource approval processor.

Specify the limits for resources including CPU and memory available in the namespace. 
(Defaults: Default resource quota limits/ defaultRequest: Default resource quota request limits)

GENERAL.MSG_MENUSETTINGS_MAIN_DESCRIPTION_1: The sidebar of the HyperCloud console provides access to the platform's main features and functions. Administrators can create customized sidebar policies in order to limit access to certain features for specific users.

GENERAL.MSG_NAMESPACES_MAIN_TABNAMESPACES_DESCRI: Namespaces are a logical partitioning capability that allows you to specify resource allocation range such as CPU and memory. The claim function is used to enable the resource approval processor.
GENERAL.MSG_NAMESPACES_MAIN_TABNAMESPACECLAIMS_D: A namespace claim is a creation request for a namespace. Each namespace claim must specify resources such as CPU and memory and the amount needed. Namespace administrators can approve or reject these claims.
